summary: Tony Varona is mentioned in three documents. In one document, he is referred to in a contact report where John D. Peters reports on a meeting with AMRUNG-1, a leader of the AMTIM group in Cuba, discussing operational support, security concerns, and assessments of other anti-Castro groups and leaders. Another document mentions him in the context of William Harvey's testimony concerning Operation Mongoose, ZRRIFLE, and potential executive actions, including references to assassination plots and contacts with the criminal syndicate. The third document mentions him in a memorandum evaluating Edward J. Hamilton's manuscript, "Give Us This Day; CIA and the Bay of Pigs Invasion," which details CIA's role in the Bay of Pigs invasion from an insider's perspective and criticizes certain figures in the Kennedy Administration.
significance: Tony Varona appears to be connected to anti-Castro activities and potentially related CIA operations, including Operation Mongoose and the Bay of Pigs invasion. His association with AMRUNG-1 and the AMTIM group suggests involvement in Cuban exile efforts against Fidel Castro. The mention alongside William Harvey and in the context of assassination plots indicates a possible link to more covert and controversial aspects of the anti-Castro movement.
